---
Given the extensive collection of gene expression data across various tissues, as reported in studies such as [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], an effective strategy to decipher these biological processes is the Transcription-Wide Association Study (TWAS). TWAS represents a powerful integrative approach that combines expression Quantitative Trait Loci (eQTLs) data with genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings. This methodology offers valuable mechanistic insights into GWAS results [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367].

However, TWAS operates at the individual gene level, which may not fully capture more intricate interactions occurring within biological networks. To address this limitation, researchers have focused on expanding TWAS's scope by considering network-level analyses, such as those based on gene regulatory mechanisms [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @pmid:33931583].

TWAS has demonstrated remarkable success in elucidating disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:31036433; @doi:10.2126/jsrs.2021.00975] and has made significant contributions to various applications, including disease-risk prediction via polygenic scores [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Context: With the accumulation of gene expression data from various tissues, there is a pressing need to identify biological processes underlying genetic associations and potential therapeutic targets.

Content: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) have emerged as an effective approach for integrating gene expression data with genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9]. These studies leverage gene expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic insights into the functional role of genetic variants in human diseases [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. TWAS has proven valuable in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], enabling advancements in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618].

Conclusion: However, TWAS focuses on individual genes, neglecting more complex interactions at the network level. In this manuscript, we will present a novel methodology that utilizes gene co-expression networks to project genetic associations and uncover disease mechanisms, thereby expanding our understanding of therapeutic targets and drug repurposing opportunities.

Context: With an abundance of gene expression data collected from various tissues [@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838; @doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6; @doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776; @doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9], researchers have turned to transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) as a powerful tool for identifying biological processes involved in human diseases [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].

Content: TWAS is a methodology that combines gene expression data with genetic variants, or eQTLs, to provide insights into the molecular mechanisms underlying genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. This approach has proven successful in elucidating the transcriptome-level etiology of numerous diseases [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433]. Furthermore, TWAS has advanced our understanding of disease risk prediction [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w], drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618], and other applications [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433].

Conclusion: While TWAS has been instrumental in advancing our knowledge of gene expression and disease associations at the individual gene level, it does not capture more intricate interactions occurring within biological networks. Future studies are necessary to develop methods that can extend the capabilities of TWAS beyond single genes and provide a more comprehensive understanding of the molecular mechanisms underlying human diseases.

Context: With the increasing availability of gene expression data across various tissues, there is a growing need to identify biological processes associated with complex traits and diseases.

Content: Transcription-wide association studies (TWAS) represent an effective approach to this challenge by integrating expression quantitative trait loci (eQTLs) data to provide mechanistic interpretations for genome-wide association study (GWAS) findings [@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482; @doi:10.1038/ng.3506; @doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889; @doi:10.1038/ng.3367]. These studies have been instrumental in understanding disease etiology at the transcriptome level [@pmid:33931583; @doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225; @pmid:31036433], enabling advances in disease-risk prediction (polygenic scores) [@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w] and drug repurposing [@doi:10.1038/nn.4618]. However, TWAS primarily focus on individual genes, leaving unexplored the more complex interactions at the network level.

Conclusion: To address this limitation, our study employs a gene co-expression analysis methodology to project genetic associations through gene expression patterns and uncover disease etiology and potential drug mechanisms. This approach not only complements existing TWAS methods but also offers new insights into the clustering of complex traits [@pmid:31526047; @doi:10.1186/s13059-020-00216-9]. By integrating gene expression data and genetic associations at the network level, we aim to provide a more comprehensive understanding of disease mechanisms and identify novel therapeutic targets.

description = "Does not make up references to other articles"
type = "Information accuracy"
score = 2.0

import re

input = context["vars"]["content"]

references = {
  "@doi:10.1038/nbt.3838",
  "@doi:10.1038/s41467-018-03751-6",
  "@doi:10.1126/science.aaz1776",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13040-020-00216-9",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1009482",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3506",
  "@doi:10.1371/journal.pgen.1007889",
  "@doi:10.1038/ng.3367",
  "@pmid:33931583",
  "@doi:10.1101/2021.10.21.21265225",
  "@pmid:31036433",
  "@doi:10.1186/s13059-021-02591-w",
  "@doi:10.1038/nn.4618",
}

# keep only references that are present in the input (this is needed because
#  references might be removed from the input in some cases)
references = [ref for ref in references if ref in input]

# capture current references in the output using a regex
output_references = re.findall(r'@[^ ;\]]+', output)

n_fake_refs = len([ref for ref in output_references if ref not in references])
res = (n_fake_refs == 0)

return {
  "pass": res,
  "score": score if res else 0.0,
  "reason": "Passed" if res else "Failed",
  "assertion": {
    "value": description,
    "type": type,
  },
}
